description: <p>pdfmake 0.1.40 已发布，pdfmake 是基于客户端和服务端的 PDF 打印解决方案，基于 JavaScript 开发，提供强大的排版引擎。</p><p><strong>更新内容：</strong></p><ul class=" list-paddingleft-2"><li><p>updated default Roboto font to latest version 2.137</p></li><li><p>updated file-saver to 2.0.0 and removed hacks for Web Worker</p></li><li><p>implemented text&nbsp;<code>opacity</code></p></li><li><p>allow passing tableLayouts, fonts and vfs to createPdf instead of using global pdfMake.&nbsp;<code>pdfMake.createPdf(docDefinition, tableLayouts, fonts, vfs)</code>&nbsp;(see readme)</p></li></ul><p>Bugfixes:</p><ul class=" list-paddingleft-2"><li><p>fixed text opacity after transparent image</p></li></ul><p><strong>下载地址：</strong></p><ul class=" list-paddingleft-2"><li><p><a data-cke-saved-href="https://github.com/bpampuch/pdfmake/archive/0.1.40.zip" href="https://github.com/bpampuch/pdfmake/archive/0.1.40.zip">Source code(zip)</a></p></li><li><p><a data-cke-saved-href="https://github.com/bpampuch/pdfmake/archive/0.1.40.tar.gz" href="https://github.com/bpampuch/pdfmake/archive/0.1.40.tar.gz">Source code(tar.gz)</a></p></li></ul>
rss_title: 开源中国社区最新新闻
title: pdfmake 0.1.40 发布，PDF 打印解决方案

description: <p>NuTyX 10.5 已正式发布！</p><p>NuTyX 是一份法语 Linux 发行，它从 Linux From Scratch 和 Beyond Linux From Scratch 而创建，并带有一份定制的包管理系统叫做 cards。该包管理器能安装单独的二进制软件包，也能安装一组相关联的二进制包（例如 KDE 或 Xfce 这样的桌面软件包），还能从 ports 编译源代码包。该发行面向中级和高级 Linux 用户而设计。</p><p>与 10.4 相比，NuTyX 10.5 的主要包含以下更新：<br/></p><ul class=" list-paddingleft-2"><li><p>kernel lts 4.14.78 -&gt; 4.14.89</p></li><li><p>kernel 4.18.16 -&gt; 4.19.11</p></li><li><p>firefox 62.0.3 -&gt; 64.0</p></li><li><p>chromium 70.0.3538.67</p></li><li><p>libreoffice 6.1.2.1</p></li><li><p>kde Applications 18.08.2 -&gt; 18.12.0</p></li><li><p>kde framework 5.50.0 -&gt; 5.53.0</p></li><li><p>kde plasma 5.12.6 LTS</p></li></ul><p>发行说明：<a data-cke-saved-href="http://nutyx.org/en/news" target="_blank" href="http://nutyx.org/en/news">http://nutyx.org/en/news</a></p><p>下载地址：<a data-cke-saved-href="http://nutyx.org/en/downloads" target="_blank" href="http://nutyx.org/en/downloads">http://nutyx.org/en/downloads</a></p><p><img data-cke-saved-src="https://static.oschina.net/uploads/space/2018/1022/074032_2g2e_2720166.png" src="https://static.oschina.net/uploads/space/2018/1022/074032_2g2e_2720166.png"/></p>
rss_title: 开源中国社区最新新闻
title: NuTyX 10.5 正式发布，法语 Linux 发行版

rss_title: 极客公园
title: 连微信也做起了「时刻视频」，Stories 到底好玩在哪里？

description: <p>这是一位互联网圈为数不多的女性 CTO，15 岁上大学，曾是腾讯获得 S 级荣誉的最年轻管理者之一。2014 年，邱慧加入优信，从零开始孵化优信二手车。人们很难将这样一位姑娘同 CTO 的头衔联系在一起，更何况是在二手车这样一个厚重的产业当中。这一次，颖奇和这位性格直率的 CTO 聊了聊关于二手车产业当中的技术价值。原来，在这个传统行业当中，也充满了闪亮迷人的技术信仰。<br></p><p><br></p><h2><span style="font-weight: bold;">行业价值核心：检测与定价的效率</span></h2><p><strong>颖奇：邱总您好，很高兴您这次能接受我们的访谈，能否先跟大家介绍一下你自己呢？</strong></p><p>邱慧：先简单说一下之前的经历吧，北大毕业后我去了微软亚洲研究院，参与了中国第一个 LBS 项目，后来加入了腾讯，参与腾讯研究院的组建，先后孵化了 QQ 拼音、QQ 影音以及微信视频聊天等产品。2014 年我加入优信，从零开始搭建团队和孵化产品，包括优信二手车、优信新车、汽车简历等。</p><p><strong>颖奇：现在团队的人员规模是怎么样的？</strong></p><p>邱慧：我们团队数百人，由于二手车产业链很复杂，产品技术团队工作划分比较精细，除了大家见到的优信二手车 App 这个面向 C 端的产品，我们还会做很多后端管理及运营的产品，会有一些黑科技，比如车辆的检测、智能定价、VR 看车等。</p><p><strong>颖奇：能详细举例说说车辆检测的技术应用吗？</strong></p><p>邱慧：举个例子，在我们做智能检测之前，中国的二手车检测基本是人工检测。人工检测有很大的局限性。第一，有经验的老师傅非常少；其次，人是非常主观的动物，比如偷个懒或心情不好导致出现失误都是难免的，很多车辆有问题没法被发现；第三，人的效率是不高的，因为我们不可能 24 小时工作。人工检查一辆车的外观需要整整 40 分钟，而我们做了一个自动化的检测设备，只需要十秒。</p><p>我们做了两个很重要的设备：一个叫做龙门。龙门是一个 360 度的棚子，上面有非常多的相机，地上有底盘检测仪，前面有一个栏杆，好像进停车场一样，车辆开过去的时候，栏杆抬起来，然后车子开进去，栏杆放下来的一瞬间车辆的外观报告就出来了。整个过程只需要十秒钟。利用这样的流程进行拍照，在云端进行图像识别，最后给出结果。</p><p>那这个结果能做什么呢？能告诉我们比如车辆的左前方有一个几厘米的划痕，还能告诉我们这样大小的划痕可能要折价一千块钱左右。自动化提供这么详尽的数据，相当于我们把人工的检测时间从 40 分钟缩短到十秒，极大提高了效率。这是龙门。</p><p>另一个设备叫查客。查客是一个软硬件一体的手持设备，大家都知道只要被撞过、修复过、重新喷过漆，车表面的厚度跟之前就是不一样的，相差 0.1 微米我们也能检查出来。相当于检测员拿这个手持设备对车进行扫描，我们就知道这个车之前有没有剐蹭过。</p><p><strong>颖奇：通过技术设备的检测结果和经由老师傅检测的结果一样么？</strong></p><p>邱慧：（设备检测结果）比老师傅准确多了。靠肉眼去看，人的精力有限；另外车辆的品牌车系特别多，一个非常懂宝马的师傅，不一定能够懂得奔驰或丰田。系统的一个好处是，它会进行机器学习、累积样本，并且越来越准确。所以我们不光是时间缩短了，准确度也提升了。</p><p>2015 年我们组建了优信的人工智能团队，是整个业界最早用人工智能系统去帮助车辆检测提高效率和准确度的公司。我们现在的图像识别准确度已经到 99.7% 了，已经是非常高的水平了。</p><p><strong>颖奇：质量检测和匹配定价的效率才是核心？</strong></p><p>邱慧：对，其实二手车行业在国外发展比较成熟，在中国为什么不成熟？是因为中国人觉得二手车这个行业水很深。归结起来痛点有两个：一是质量、二是价格。质量就是不知道有没有出过事故，价格的话，就是不晓得这个价格到底高还是低。技术可以解决质量检测的问题，也可以解决价格这个痛点。二手车定价是非常有难度的事情，我们也是花了整整一年的时间去打磨。</p><p><strong>颖奇：那你们通过什么判断价格呢？</strong></p><p>邱慧：二手车的定价受到各种因素限制，包括城市、里程、年限、保养情况、有没有出过事故等上千个指标。传统的定价方式是靠人的经验拍脑袋。而我们在国内最早采用了神经网络去建模。另外，由于介入了整个交易流程，优信有最完整的成交数据。有了大数据的积累我们的模型才能够不断迭代优化。</p><p><strong>颖奇：关于二手车的大额分期业务，优信在技术上做了哪些努力呢？</strong></p><p>邱慧：这个也是我们在业界非常早的用技术去实现的。分期涉及到风控，我们能够做到千人千面，给你提供一个非常适合你的金融分期解决方案，让你买到自己想要的车。我们在贷前、贷中和贷后三个环节都做了非常多系统化的建模处理，包括自动化信审、风险预警等等，去识别风险，提升风控水平。</p><p><strong>颖奇：那您觉得优信在二手车这个商业模式下再往后走的话，有哪些更重要的技术是优信会去做早期准备的呢？</strong></p><p>邱慧：有挺多的，比如我们最近已经上线但还在打磨中的 VR 看车。一方面我们要通过不停的优化软硬件一体的整个系统模型，追求更高清的图像质量、更高保真的还原度、更高效的拍摄模式，从而快速大量的为用户提供可靠且高质量的 VR 车源数据；另一方面利用 AI 人工智能系统在后台统计数据来完善升级我们的 VR 看车系统，比如用户通过 VR 看车更愿意在哪一个角度放大关注汽车的哪一个细节，数据告诉我们相当一部分用户关注汽车的车轮毂和内饰座椅。通过数据支撑，我们再想办法反向继续优化我们系统模型，这些数据与技术的积累优化可以直接转化为用户的体验。</p><p>因为我们定位是一个二手车电商平台。那么二手车的电商属性是什么呢？就是实现用户在网上就能够下决策。</p><p>一来 VR 看车不会受限于时间地域空间，让用户在线上就能感受这个车怎么样，车况满不满意，空间合不合适，用户不用辛苦地跑到停车场就能看到车内车外的每一个细节，省时又省力，这些优质的体验感都会促使购车者做出决策。二是没有什么比「真实」更具有说服力，而我们正在研发的「沉浸式 VR 看车」，就感觉自己好像真的坐进去了一样，感受下，「哦空间挺大的，我喜欢空间大的」；或者说「哎，我喜欢这个真皮座椅」。这样就尽可能在线上做好决策了，线上做好决策后去线下可能看一眼就购买了。相当于尽可能减少用户在线下做决策的时间，拉长在线上做决定的时间。</p><p><br></p><h2><span style="font-weight: bold;">「重」行业中的 CTO 如何主动升级</span></h2><p><strong>颖奇：您当年去做&nbsp;</strong><strong>to C&nbsp;</strong><strong>的产品，最终转过来做像汽车行业这么重的一个全产业链平台</strong><strong>，</strong><strong>您觉得您作为一个技术人或者产品人，您自己最大的变化是什么。</strong></p><p>邱慧：我觉得在商业思维方面有非常大的提升，包括整体的管理能力等。因为我以前做纯 to C，属于单边服务，只需要服务好一边的用户。但是二手车属于双边，甚至多边，涉及 B2C，C2B，B2B 等，商户和用户都是我的用户，这个思路是不一样的。</p><p><strong>颖奇：您在&nbsp;</strong><strong>2014&nbsp;</strong><strong>年从零开始搭建团队，有没有哪些从量变到质变的一些管理研发很难跨越的坎？</strong></p><p>邱慧：量变到质变的过程是最大的坎。当人员快速扩张的时候，从几十人到百人到几百人需要的管理方式是不一样的。需要带着大家制定标准和流程，需要在团队内部建立良好的沟通反馈机制，需要关注不同层级员工的成长和发展。当把几百人的坎迈过去之后，后面团队再增长也能继续保持高人效了。</p><p><strong>颖奇：怎么能够激发大家的积极性一起成长呢？</strong></p><p>邱慧：其实每个人的需求都不太一样，首先我们需要了解他想要的是什么，明确诉求，采用不同的帮助和激励机制。例如我们有 mentor 制度，每一个新员工进来都有 mentor 指定给他去帮助他。另外，我会要求所有管理者都必须跟直系下属定期进行 One on One，两周一次，强制要求，写在 KPI 中的。大家可以聊最近工作的情况、个人状态、生活中的变化等等，鼓励大家主动说，管理者给予反馈，形成良好的沟通机制。诉求得到满足，感受到尊重和鼓励，大家自然对团队认同感高，积极性高。</p><p><strong>颖奇：我相信一些采访过您的人也问过，可能行业里面女生做&nbsp;</strong><strong>CTO&nbsp;</strong><strong>的会比较少，所以你会认为女性&nbsp;</strong><strong>CTO&nbsp;</strong><strong>比男性&nbsp;</strong><strong>CTO&nbsp;</strong><strong>有更好的优势吗？</strong></p><p>邱慧：你说的很对，女性 CTO 比较少。首先因为技术是非常理性和抽象的思维方法，逻辑性要很强，可能大部分女生会感性一些。所以如果一个人的理性思维比较强，是会有助于他在技术和产品方面做管理和决策。但同时，我认为女性管理者更善于刚柔并济，能够很容易洞悉团队里面的问题，能够很好的调动团队积极性，能够非常好的跟大家互动交流，这对于程序员比较多的技术团队很重要。</p><p><strong>颖奇：聊了这么多，</strong><strong>您可以</strong><strong>给大家推荐一些您最近在看的或者看过觉得有意思的书籍吗？</strong></p><p>邱慧：最近在看《激情创业》《卓有成效的管理者》《基业长青》等等。</p><p><strong>颖奇：最后，想请您总结一下，在吸引人才方面，一个人为什么应该加入优信二手车，是什么让他觉得来这里会比他去别的公司更好？</strong></p><p>邱慧：我们并不盲目只通过高薪去吸引人才，而是给予优秀的人充分的发展空间和机会。在优信这样的快速发展的公司，我们需要的是一群真正想做事的人，大家有激情、有信念、追求成就感。</p><p><strong>颖奇：优信有非常好的人才理念。非常感谢您的分享。</strong></p><p>本文作者：王颖奇</p><p>联系方式：wangyingqi@gmail.com</p>

description: <html><head></head><body><div class="block-paragraph"><div class="rich-text"><p>Seeing music. Predicting earthquake aftershocks. Finding emojis in real life. These are just a few examples of how researchers, engineers and user-experience (UX) professionals made imaginative ideas real. They made it happen using tools and techniques developed by Google’s People + AI Research (PAIR) team in 2018.</p><p>We founded PAIR in 2017 to <a href="https://ai.google/research/teams/brain/pair">conduct research</a>, <a href="https://medium.com/google-design/human-centered-machine-learning-a770d10562cd">create design frameworks</a> and <a href="https://github.com/PAIR-code">build new technologies</a> that help make partnerships between humans and artificial intelligence productive, enjoyable and fair. One of our main goals is to create easy-to-use tools to <a href="https://pair-code.github.io/facets/">visualize machine learning (ML) datasets</a> and <a href="https://js.tensorflow.org/">train ML models</a> (the mathematical equations that represent the steps a machine will complete to make a decision) in browsers. Put simply, this means anyone with an internet connection can now use ML.</p><p>Here’s what PAIR has accomplished over the past year—and here’s how engineers and UX teams can put our resources to use in 2019 and beyond.</p><h3>Creating a design library—and learning how to design for AI</h3><p>In January, we launched <a href="https://design.google/library/ai/">a library</a> of user-experience articles and case studies on <a href="https://design.google/">Google Design</a>. These show how Google makes decisions to balance our users’ needs for familiarity and trust with new functionality and experiences enabled by AI. The case studies go behind the scenes to show how Google teams developed user experiences for applications, like the fun mobile game <a href="https://design.google/library/designing-emoji-scavengerhunt/">Emoji Scavenger Hunt</a>.</p><p>In these articles, practicing user-experience designers offer clear how-tos. They address challenges in designing for AI, such as balancing how to design for habits like swiping or scrolling in certain directions, and building <a href="https://design.google/library/predictably-smart/">personalized experiences</a> for individual users. We know we don’t have all the answers, so we also seek advice from outside experts, like Paola Antonelli, Senior Curator of Architecture and Design at New York’s Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), who <a href="https://design.google/library/ai-designs-latest-material/">answered our team’s questions </a>on how to use AI as a design material itself.</p><h3>Talking about AI across disciplines</h3><p>A key part of our process is partnering with domain experts in other fields. For example, this year we worked with Harvard’s Brendan Meade and the University of Connecticut’s Phoebe de Vries on a model for <a href="https://www.blog.google/technology/ai/forecasting-earthquake-aftershock-locations-ai-assisted-science/">predicting and visualizing earthquake aftershocks</a>. This project led to a state-of-the-art model for aftershock prediction--and, intriguingly, our analysis of the  AI suggested new, unexpected directions for human researchers to investigate.<br/></p><p>In March, we  hosted our first <a href="https://sites.google.com/corp/view/pair-ux-symposium-march-2018/speakers-talks?authuser=0">UX symposium</a> in Zurich, featuring external researchers and industry professionals. And in May, we held a panel at  I/O, “<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=106&amp;v=_JCImtDa0Jk">AI for Everyone</a>,” featuring Google engineering leaders with a spectrum of expertise, from cloud computing to climate science, to discuss fair and inclusive AI in these fields.</p><p>We’re also dedicated to translating the complicated language behind AI for everyone who uses it, even if they’re not engineers. Since June, our first PAIR writer-in-residence, tech journalist <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/david-weinberger-0131/">David Weinberger</a>, has been embedded in PAIR’s Cambridge, Mass. lab. He’s explaining key AI concepts, like <a href="https://accelerate.withgoogle.com/stories/ai-outside-in-machine-learnings-triangle-of-error">classification</a> and <a href="https://accelerate.withgoogle.com/stories/ai-outside-in-confidence-everywhere">confidence levels</a>, and timely topics like <a href="https://pair-code.github.io/what-if-tool/ai-fairness.html">fairness in machine learning</a>, for non-technical audiences.</p><h3>New open-source tools for engineers, UXers and beyond</h3></div></div><div class="block-image_full_width"><div class="article-module h-c-page"><div class="h-c-grid"><figure class="article-image--large h-c-grid__col h-c-grid__col--6 h-c-grid__col--offset-3 "><img alt="Seeing Music" src="https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-uniblog-publish-prod/original_images/Seeing_Music.gif"/><figcaption class="article-image__caption "><div class="rich-text"><p>Using TensorFlow.js, an open-source Javascript library created by PAIR, and other software, a group of musicians, designers, engineers and the Google Creative Lab created <a href="https://experiments.withgoogle.com/seeing-music">Seeing Music</a>, which makes it possible to visualize subtle textures in sound.</p></div></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="block-paragraph"><div class="rich-text"><p>We believe in applying deep insights to invent, and open-source, new technologies that can be used by engineers, UX professionals, and other stakeholders who may not be experts in ML.</p><p>So we started <a href="https://js.tensorflow.org/">TensorFlow.js</a>, a pure Javascript library that extends <a href="https://www.tensorflow.org/">TensorFlow</a> into the browser. Since open-sourcing TensorFlow.js in March, we've seen a variety of applications–including a set of <a href="https://experiments.withgoogle.com/collection/creatability">accessible creative tools</a> for drawing, making music and more, designed by Google’s Creative Lab with collaborators from the accessibility community.</p></div></div><div class="block-video"><div class="h-c-page h-c-page--mobile-full-bleed"><div class="h-c-grid"><div class="h-c-grid__col h-c-grid__col-l--12 "><div class="article-module article-video "><figure><a class="h-c-video h-c-video--marquee" data-glue-modal-disabled-on-mobile="true" data-glue-modal-trigger="uni-modal-c5-bHJqtQS0-" href="https://youtube.com/watch?v=c5-bHJqtQS0"><img alt="Creatability: Exploring ways to make creative tools more accessible for everyone" src="//img.youtube.com/vi/c5-bHJqtQS0/maxresdefault.jpg"/><svg class="h-c-video__play h-c-icon h-c-icon--color-white" role="img"><use xlink:href="#mi-youtube-icon"></use></svg></a></figure></div></div></div></div><div class="h-c-modal--video" data-glue-modal="uni-modal-c5-bHJqtQS0-" data-glue-modal-close-label="Close Dialog"><a class="glue-yt-video" data-glue-yt-video-autoplay="true" data-glue-yt-video-height="99%" data-glue-yt-video-vid="c5-bHJqtQS0" data-glue-yt-video-width="100%" href="https://youtube.com/watch?v=c5-bHJqtQS0" ng-cloak=""></a></div></div><div class="block-paragraph"><div class="rich-text"><p>Our PAIR team also built the <a href="https://pair-code.github.io/what-if-tool/">What-If Tool</a>, released this fall, so professionals building ML systems don’t have to write a single line of code to answer “what if” questions such as: “What if I changed data points, how would this affect my model’s predictions? Does it perform differently for various groups–for example, historically marginalized people?" Our tool makes it possible to simply click a button to visualize and inspect alternative scenarios.</p><p></p><p>Also this year, our team developed and open-sourced <a href="https://github.com/tensorflow/tcav/">a new technique</a> for helping people more easily understand the inner workings of neural networks in terms of simple, human-understandable concepts – like showing how AI can recognize images of zebras by their stripes.</p><p>In 2019, we’re excited to expand PAIR’s work further with global audiences of engineers and user-experience designers–and everyday users. For more resources, updates and information on our research, <a href="https://ai.google/research/teams/brain/pair">head to PAIR’s website</a>.</p></div></div></body></html>
rss_title: The Keyword
title: How we worked to make AI for everyone in 2018

rss_title: 极客公园
title: 真的，Pornhub 比今日头条或是 Netflix 更了解你爱看什么

description: <html><head></head><body><div class="block-paragraph"><div class="rich-text"><p>If I had to summarize 2018 in one word ... it would probably be “<a href="https://youtu.be/6aFdEhEZQjE?t=83">flossing</a>” (kids, am I doing this right?). But let’s put the dance moves aside for a minute. As my dentist continually reminds me, it’s easy to miss stuff when you don’t take enough time to look in the mirror, really focus, and ... floss. No, reflect! Reflect. So while 2018 is still (minty) fresh in our minds, we’re taking a moment to take another look at some things you may have missed from us this year:</p></div></div><div class="block-paragraph"><div class="rich-text"><p><b>1.</b> AI is behind many products at Google, but this year it created some <a href="https://www.blog.google/technology/ai/making-music-using-new-sounds-generated-machine-learning/">new beats</a>, took a shot <a href="https://www.blog.google/technology/ai/one-shining-ai-moment-when-machine-learning-meets-your-bracket/">with the NCAA</a> during March Madness, and took us on a <a href="https://www.blog.google/technology/ai/emojis-irl-find-them-using-machine-learning/">scavenger hunt</a> to find emoji. But what about those of us who aren’t DJs or data scientists? There are lots of ways you’re already encountering AI in your <a href="https://www.blog.google/technology/ai/13-ways-youre-using-ai-your-daily-life/">daily life</a>. </p><p><b>2.</b> We met many a Googler this year—from <a href="https://www.blog.google/inside-google/working-google/between-two-interns-scoop-summer-google/">interns</a> to our <a href="https://blog.google/inside-google/googlers/she-word/our-do-list-interview-googles-productivity-expert/">resident productivity expert</a> to the <a href="https://www.blog.google/products/chromecast/heres-five-years-chromecast/">couple behind Chromecast</a>—who gave us an inside look into what they do and how they do it. We went back in time to learn about Google execs’ <a href="https://www.blog.google/inside-google/googlers/throwing-it-back-google-leaders-share-their-first-summer-jobs/">first summer jobs</a>, and saw a glimpse of the future that one Googler <a href="https://www.blog.google/inside-google/googlers/ara-star-engineer/">imagines in her children’s book</a>: “propelling girls in the direction of exploring coding and engineering.”</p><p></p><p></p><p></p><p><b>3.</b> Though we spent lots of time with Googlers in the wild, we also had some fun with animals during the <a href="https://www.blog.google/around-the-globe/google-asia/happy-lunar-new-year-wag-hello-year-dog/">Year of the Dog</a>. A pack of adorable Akita dogs made their <a href="https://www.blog.google/products/maps/pup-view-home-japans-adorable-akita-dogs/">debut on Street View</a>, a farm in the Netherlands is <a href="https://www.blog.google/technology/ai/using-tensorflow-keep-farmers-happy-and-cows-healthy/">using TensorFlow</a> to track the health of its cows, and a <a href="https://www.blog.google/inside-google/working-google/every-summer-googles-campus-birds/">flock of egrets</a> landed at the Googleplex for the summer. </p><p></p><p></p><p></p><p></p></div></div><div class="block-video"><div class="h-c-page h-c-page--mobile-full-bleed"><div class="h-c-grid"><div class="h-c-grid__col h-c-grid__col-l--12 "><div class="article-module article-video "><figure><a class="h-c-video h-c-video--marquee" data-glue-modal-disabled-on-mobile="true" data-glue-modal-trigger="uni-modal-FMf57MAgoS0-" href="https://youtube.com/watch?v=FMf57MAgoS0"><img alt="“Dog View” from Akita-inu" src="//img.youtube.com/vi/FMf57MAgoS0/maxresdefault.jpg"/><svg class="h-c-video__play h-c-icon h-c-icon--color-white" role="img"><use xlink:href="#mi-youtube-icon"></use></svg></a><figcaption class="article-video__caption h-c-page"><p>See more of these snow pups on Street View.</p></figcaption></figure></div></div></div></div><div class="h-c-modal--video" data-glue-modal="uni-modal-FMf57MAgoS0-" data-glue-modal-close-label="Close Dialog"><a class="glue-yt-video" data-glue-yt-video-autoplay="true" data-glue-yt-video-height="99%" data-glue-yt-video-vid="FMf57MAgoS0" data-glue-yt-video-width="100%" href="https://youtube.com/watch?v=FMf57MAgoS0" ng-cloak=""></a></div></div><div class="block-paragraph"><div class="rich-text"><p></p><b>4.</b>We <a href="https://blog.google/perspectives/mary-ellen-coe/why-were-committed-helping-small-businesses-grow/">continued our commitment</a> to empowering small businesses around the world, whether they were veteran-run <a href="https://blog.google/outreach-initiatives/small-business/veteran-led-business-strengthening-hearts-and-minds/">yoga studios</a> and<a href="https://blog.google/outreach-initiatives/small-business/veteran-small-business/">craft breweries</a> or <a href="https://blog.google/outreach-initiatives/grow-with-google/meet-alex-spanish-jobseeker-whose-app-brought-work-thousands/">job-posting apps</a> in Spain. And we also <a href="https://blog.google/outreach-initiatives/small-business/start-new-page-today/">launched the .page top-level domain</a> for businesses to showcase their work.<p></p><p><b>5.</b>Through products like Street View, VR and Arts and Culture, we took you on <a href="https://blog.google/products/maps/blind-kayakers-grand-canyon/">a kayaking trip with blind veterans</a> through the Grand Canyon, a frigid arctic expedition to <a href="https://blog.google/products/maps/building-map-canadas-north/">Canada’s high north</a>, and a <a href="https://blog.google/products/maps/shellebrating-christmas-islands-extraordinary-nature-street-view-and-google-earth/">crab migration</a> in the "Australian Galapagos." We don’t take the word "magical" lightly around here, but when you're taking people to <a href="https://www.blog.google/products/maps/its-street-view-after-all-disney-parks-come-google-maps/">Disney parks</a> and <a href="https://blog.google/outreach-initiatives/arts-culture/just-flick-wand-harry-potter-history-magic-google-arts-culture/">the world of Harry Potter</a>, well ... if the slipper fits…</p><p></p></div></div><div class="block-image_full_width"><figure class="article-image--full article-module "><img alt="Churchill Canada.gif" src="https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-uniblog-publish-prod/original_images/Churchill_Canada.gif"/><figcaption class="article-image__caption h-c-page"><div class="rich-text"><p>In Canada's high north, don't forget your gloves.</p></div></figcaption></figure></div><div class="block-paragraph"><div class="rich-text"><br/><p><b>6.</b>We heard from a <a href="https://blog.google/products/earth/finding-my-way-back-antarctica-help-google-earth/">daring climber</a> and <a href="https://www.blog.google/outreach-initiatives/google-org/lin-manuel-miranda-supporting-puerto-ricos-recovery/">Lin-Manuel Miranda</a> about places that are important to them, and traveled <a href="https://blog.google/products/maps/wheres-waldo-find-him-google-maps/">around the world with Waldo</a>—stopping along the way at <a href="https://www.blog.google/products/pixel/two-teampixel-photographers-say-i-do-pixel-2/">a wedding</a> and the <a href="https://www.blog.google/outreach-initiatives/education/calling-all-young-dreamers-and-problem-solvers-google-science-fair-open/">Google science fair</a>.</p><p><b>7. </b>We turned 20 this year! During our <a href="https://blog.google/google-20/">month-long celebration</a>, we went back to our roots <a href="https://www.blog.google/products/maps/inside-googles-original-garage-1998-style/">in the garage</a>, recalled oodles of <a href="https://blog.google/inside-google/doodles/doodle-me-20-notable-doodles-google-history/">Doodles through history</a>, and examined how our mission applies to the <a href="https://blog.google/technology/next-billion-users/how-insights-user-research-help-us-build-next-billion-users/">next billion users</a>. And as icing on the (birthday) cake, we put together some <a href="https://blog.google/inside-google/company-announcements/twenty-years-building-everyone/">highlights from two decades</a> of Google history.</p></div></div><div class="block-video"><div class="h-c-page h-c-page--mobile-full-bleed"><div class="h-c-grid"><div class="h-c-grid__col h-c-grid__col-l--12 "><div class="article-module article-video "><figure><a class="h-c-video h-c-video--marquee" data-glue-modal-disabled-on-mobile="true" data-glue-modal-trigger="uni-modal-KoeXTH1_EN8-" href="https://youtube.com/watch?v=KoeXTH1_EN8"><img alt="Explore Google’s original garage with Street View" src="//img.youtube.com/vi/KoeXTH1_EN8/maxresdefault.jpg"/><svg class="h-c-video__play h-c-icon h-c-icon--color-white" role="img"><use xlink:href="#mi-youtube-icon"></use></svg></a><figcaption class="article-video__caption h-c-page"><p>Going back to the garage where it all began.</p></figcaption></figure></div></div></div></div><div class="h-c-modal--video" data-glue-modal="uni-modal-KoeXTH1_EN8-" data-glue-modal-close-label="Close Dialog"><a class="glue-yt-video" data-glue-yt-video-autoplay="true" data-glue-yt-video-height="99%" data-glue-yt-video-vid="KoeXTH1_EN8" data-glue-yt-video-width="100%" href="https://youtube.com/watch?v=KoeXTH1_EN8" ng-cloak=""></a></div></div><div class="block-paragraph"><div class="rich-text"><p><b>8. </b>We got organized, and made a few lists of different ways to use our products, whether you’re <a href="https://www.blog.google/products/pixel/four-tips-taking-delectable-food-photos-pixel-2/">taking food pics like a pro</a> with your Pixel or consulting Google Maps to <a href="https://www.blog.google/products/maps/six-google-maps-travel-hacks-make-your-best-summer-yet/">plan your travels</a>. The <a href="https://www.blog.google/technology/developers/all-io18-announcements/">list of I/O announcements</a> made it to 100, but for our products with a billion users, we went <a href="https://blog.google/products/search/tips-people-behind-your-favorite-google-products/">straight to the source</a>.</p><p><b>9. </b>We believe that technology creates more opportunities for those who might not have access to it—and this year, we saw proof of this from <a href="https://blog.google/outreach-initiatives/small-business/father-son-business-creating-jobs-and-spreading-happiness-through-socks/">sock sellers</a>, <a href="https://blog.google/outreach-initiatives/education/girls-across-country-learning-code-magical-mary-poppins/">creative coders</a> and organizations like <a href="https://blog.google/outreach-initiatives/google-org/ai4all-participants-tell-allsummer-camps-get-girls-involved-ai-and-tech/">AI4ALL</a>. Whether in <a href="https://blog.google/around-the-globe/google-asia/code-in-the-community/">Singapore</a> or in our own <a href="https://blog.google/outreach-initiatives/diversity/leveling-stem-playing-field-girls-one-robot-time/">Northern California backyard</a>, we’re excited to introduce even more people to coding in 2019.</p></div></div><div class="block-image_full_width"><figure class="article-image--full article-module "><img alt="Girl Scouts robotics" src="https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-uniblog-publish-prod/images/Copy_of_Copy_of_DSC03627.max-1000x1000.jpg"/><figcaption class="article-image__caption h-c-page"><div class="rich-text"><p>Girl scouts at a robotic competition, coached by Googlers</p></div></figcaption></figure></div><div class="block-paragraph"><div class="rich-text"><p><b>10.</b> Any year has its ups and downs, but through it all, were heartened by the stories of people using our products in inspiring ways. Two of those stories come from <a href="https://www.blog.google/outreach-initiatives/accessibility/robbie-iveys-story-how-technology-removes-barriers/">Robbie Ivey</a>and <a href="https://blog.google/products/search/making-morse-code-available-more-people-gboard/">Tania Finlayson</a>, people who aren’t defined by their disabilities—instead, they’re using Google products to live a more independent life. Another story hits close to home—a Googler <a href="https://blog.google/products/translate/refugee-family-translate/">helped a refugee family</a> using Google Translate, and make some lifelong friends in the process.<br/></p><p>Ok, that was a lot of sweet stuff. Now it’s really time for the dentist.</p></div></div></body></html>
rss_title: The Keyword
title: A slice of Google: looking back on 2018

description: <html><head></head><body><div class="block-paragraph"><div class="rich-text"><p>It’s been a busy year for Chrome Enterprise—we welcomed <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/chrome-enterprise/announcing-two-new-acer-chromebooks-for-the-enterprise">new hardware for enterprises</a>, helped boost <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/chrome-enterprise/5-things-you-can-do-chrome-browser-increase-employee-productivity">workplace productivity</a>, and <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/chrome-enterprise/chrome-browser-for-the-enterprise-on-the-journey-with-you-for-10-years">celebrated ten years of Chrome</a>. Here’s a look at four updates you might have missed from Chrome Enterprise in 2018.</p><p><b>1. We helped businesses prepare for the era of cloud workers</b></p><p>The availability of cloud-based apps and technology has fundamentally changed the way we work, and as a result, many businesses are rethinking the devices and tools they provide their workforce. This year we commissioned <a href="http://services.google.com/fh/files/misc/forrester_tlp_rethink_technology_in_the_age_of_the_cloud_worker.pdf">a study with Forrester</a> that takes a closer look at the <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/chrome-enterprise/how-prepare-cloud-worker-era">new era of cloud workers</a>. We hosted a half-day virtual event, <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/chrome-enterprise/join-us-for-cloud-worker-live-and-learn-how-to-move-your-workforce-to-the-cloud">Cloud Worker Live</a>, to share insights and practical advice, and we’ve made all the sessions <a href="https://chromeonair.withgoogle.com/events/cloudworkerlive?utm_source=Event&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=FY18-Q4-americas-eventonair-onlineevent-er-CloudWorkerLive-nativedevices-WB&amp;utm_content=chrome-cloudworkerlive-workplace-tech-us">available to watch online</a>.</p><p>And we also want to help businesses identify the cloud workers in their organization to better support them with the right cloud-based tools. A <a href="https://cloud.google.com/files/chrome-enterprise/helpcenter/rethink_employee_segmentation_for_a_cloud_native_world.pdf">new Forrester report</a> we commissioned provides key recommendations for workforce segmentation, and we offered some insights on <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/chrome-enterprise/workforce-segmentation-in-the-new-era-of-cloud-workers">how we do it ourselves</a> here at Google.</p><p><b>2. We launched our Grab and Go program to help businesses stay productive</b></p><p>When an employee’s device isn’t working, it can have more consequences than you think—from the hours employees devote to troubleshooting devices instead of completing projects, to the time IT teams spend on repair and replacement. To address this problem for both workers and businesses, <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/chrome-enterprise/extending-googles-grab-and-go-program-businesses-so-they-can-save-time-and-money">we introduced our Grab and Go program</a> to enterprises in July. Since then, we’ve <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/chrome-enterprise/announcing-new-partners-to-help-you-bring-grab-and-go-to-your-organization">expanded the program with new partners</a>, and <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/chrome-enterprise/with-google-grab-and-go-waymo-simplifies-chromebook-loaner-program">Waymo shared with us</a> how Grab and Go has helped them support their shift workers and dispatchers. You can learn more about Grab and Go <a href="https://cloud.google.com/chrome-enterprise/grab-and-go/">on our website</a>.</p><p><b>3. We helped help admins stay up-to-date with Chrome releases</b></p><p>If looking after Chrome browser and devices is part of your job, you probably know that Chrome releases a full OS update <a href="https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/3168106?hl=en">about every 6 weeks</a>. Our new <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/chrome-admin-insider">Admin Insider series</a> gives you a quick snapshot of the most important changes so you can take action. And if you need even more info, you can now <a href="https://lp.google-mkto.com/chromeenterprise_optin.html">sign up</a> to receive new release details as they become available.</p><p><b>4. We heard from customers all over the world</b></p><p>This year we took a closer look at more than a dozen enterprises that have adopted Chrome Enterprise in every corner of the world. For example, in India and Africa, <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/chrome-enterprise/dr-agarwals-eye-hospital-sharpens-its-focus-future-work-chromebooks-and-chromebases">Dr. Agarwal’s Eye Hospital</a> is making clinical care easier for doctors and their patients by deploying more than a thousand Chrome devices across its 70 facilities. In France, <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/customers/how-veolia-empowers-its-cloud-workers-collaborate-securely-anytime-anywhere">Veolia</a>, a global water, waste, and energy management company, is rolling out Chrome devices to all of its nearly 170,000 employees to increase productivity and collaboration across its offices on 5 different continents. And in Australia, <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/chrome-enterprise/service-nsw-empowers-customers-and-reduces-costs-chrome-enterprise">Service NSW</a> is providing better government services through Chrome-powered kiosks.</p><p>There’s a lot more to come in 2019. In the meantime, you can learn more about Chrome Enterprise <a href="https://cloud.google.com/chrome-enterprise/">on our website</a>.</p></div></div></body></html>
rss_title: The Keyword
title: Four things you might have missed from Chrome Enterprise in 2018
